prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For having a sleepover with my (21M) friend (22F) and not asking my girlfriend (20F)?
Title is pretty self explanatory but here goes.

One of my closest friends at uni, Annie (who is in a long term relationship) came over one night to have a couple of drinks before heading to a party. One of our friends bailed and we didn’t want to go to the party alone so we watched TV and smoked a couple of Js. The TV is in my room and we fell asleep together. 

My girlfriend of 2 years was at a concert with a girl friend at the time and since we had decided not to go to the party anymore went back to her place instead of coming over.

I told her the next morning that Annie fell asleep in my bed and thought nothing of it for the next few days.

The next time I saw her she sat me down and very seriously explained why she thought what had happened was super inappropriate, she also brought up a bunch of stuff that I hadn’t noticed. Like how she thought Annie would overstep boundaries by playing with my hair and holding my hand at a festival while my girlfriend was walking alone behind. This stuff did happen but I meant nothing by it and love my girlfriend to death. 

My girlfriend did say that I hadn’t done anything wrong because I had never initiated this, but I also hadn’t noticed that it had bothered her.

She said that the whole situation probably wouldn’t have bothered her if it weren’t for one conversation.

We have often talked about having threesomes and which of our friends we would sleep with. Obviously not seriously but we just find it interesting to explore each other’s tastes-and I said Annie. 

After her pointing this out I feel like I’m hyper aware of how I am acting around Annie and I fear it will change our friendship.

AITA for feeling that my GF blowed this out of proportion and letting this affect my friendship with Annie? 

TL;DR : My girlfriend got angry with me because my friend slept over in my bed and she thinks this friend crosses the line too much.


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author of the AITA post is in the wrong. The situation involves the author (a guy) having a sleepover with his female friend Annie (22F), while his girlfriend (20F) was at a concert with a friend. They ended up in his room, not going to the party, and fell asleep. The girlfriend was upset about this, partly because of past conversations about potential threesomes where the author mentioned Annie.

First, I need to consider standard relationship norms. Having a close friend sleep over in the same bed could be seen as inappropriate, especially if the girlfriend is uncomfortable. Even if the author didn't intend anything wrong, the act of not informing his girlfriend could be seen as a breach of trust. The girlfriend's reaction is about feeling her boundaries were crossed, even if the author didn't mean to cross them. 

Also, the fact that they had discussed threesomes jokingly and the author mentioned Annie might have triggered the girlfriend's insecurity. The key issue here is communication. The author didn't ask his girlfriend about the sleepover, which is a big oversight. In relationships, transparency is crucial. Even if the actions themselves were innocent, the lack of communication could be the main problem. 

From the girlfriend's perspective, she might feel that the situation was a setup for potential issues. The hyperawareness the author now feels about his friendship with Annie is a consequence of not managing expectations and communication with his girlfriend. 

So, while the author might not have malicious intent, the failure to communicate and consider his girlfriend's feelings when making plans with a close friend likely places some responsibility on him. The girlfriend's reaction, though maybe intense, is rooted in feeling overlooked and insecure. Therefore, the author could be in the wrong for not checking in with his girlfriend before the sleepover and not being more aware of her feelings in their previous interactions with Annie.
